flower the new Steven Spielberg movie
The Adventures of Tintin is just out
it's based on a series of comic books

their books about a character i'm going
to snobbishly call tan-tan because that
is how he would call himself he was the
creation of a Belgian cartoonist named
George Raimi who went by the pen name RJ
these books were drawn darting in 1929
into the 60s and they were and are
immensely successful in Europe but
they're little known in this country
because they they seem in some ways to
come from a kind of different tradition
of cartooning tanta has no superpowers
he has no romantic life he seems to have
no inner life at all that Spielberg
would would choose these comics as his
inspiration is not entirely surprising
because the comics themselves are very
cinematic there are long shots their
close-ups their sudden switches and
transitions and their meticulously drawn
on the other hand the movie doesn't look
very much like the tan tan books maybe
that's inevitable maybe it's part of
Spielberg's choice shot in in motion
capture which is a look all of its own I
think you could argue that in this movie
it almost takes over but it's a plusher
look than the original aj drawings which
have that same wonderful comic book
flatness while somehow performing that
magic trick of making the picture seem
to move the great appeal of the books is
that most of them go to an exotic locale
and they had I think four generations of
French and Belgian kids they had a kind
of documentary a travelogue function in
a very painless entertaining way they
showed you what the rest of the world
was like and the books therefore have
the great satisfactions to me of all
great genre literature which is
surprised at the same time sameness and
I think for kids and even grown-up
readers of comics there's something very
satisfying about that you know what
you're getting
RJ was himself a strange and not
entirely appealing character during the
war he worked for less warped his
Belgian paper that really actively took
the Nazi side then later in life he
underwent a kind of conversion and and
this is manifested in one of his his
late and most beautiful works tanta in
Tibet which to me is still one of the
most beautiful of the books and still
has some of that travel log magic these
books was so faithful to the Tibetan
experience that the Dalai Lama himself
actually presented tan-tan wit with an
award well deserved one I think to
testing thing to me is going to be to
see one if the movie catches on in
America and two will it drive people
back to these comic books it remains to
be seen they are dated in their way
they're old-fashioned I suppose and yet
they have an appeal of their own that
hasn't gone away they there's still
something very contemporary about them
they're just different and and maybe
different is good
